quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Forces on Inclined Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 3: Inclined Planes & Friction (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A 5.0 kg block slides down a frictionless inclined plane that makes a 30° angle with the horizontal. What is the block's acceleration down the incline?
questions.explanation: On a frictionless incline, acceleration a = g sinθ = 9.8 × sin30° = 9.8 × 0.5 = 4.9 m/s².

questions.question: A 12 kg crate is placed on a ramp inclined at 25°. The coefficient of static friction is 0.40. Will the crate begin to slide down the ramp?
options: Yes, because mg sinθ > μ_s mg cosθ
No, because friction can hold it
Yes, because μ_s is too small
No, because the angle is too shallow
questions.explanation: Calculate: mg sinθ = 12×9.8×sin25° ≈ 49.7 N. Max static friction = μ_s mg cosθ = 0.40×117.6×cos25° ≈ 42.6 N. Since 49.7 > 42.6, the crate will slide.

questions.question: A skier with total mass 65 kg descends a 20° slope. The coefficient of kinetic friction between skis and snow is 0.10. What is the skier's acceleration down the slope?
A 3.0 kg block is pushed up a 40° incline with a force of 50 N parallel to the incline. μ_k = 0.30. What is the block's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Downhill component: mg sin40° ≈ 18.90 N. Normal: mg cos40° ≈ 22.52 N. Friction: f_k = 0.30×22.52 ≈ 6.76 N (downhill, opposes motion). Net force uphill: 50 - 18.90 - 6.76 = 24.34 N. a = 24.34/3.0 ≈ 8.12 m/s² up.

questions.question: A 15 kg box is placed on a ramp inclined at 15°. μ_s = 0.35. What minimum force parallel to the incline is needed to prevent the box from sliding down?
questions.explanation: Downhill component: mg sin15° ≈ 38.04 N. Max static friction: μ_s mg cos15° ≈ 49.70 N. Since max friction > downhill force, friction alone holds it, so no additional force needed.

questions.question: A 2.0 kg block is at rest on a 35° incline. μ_s = 0.45. Does it remain at rest? If not, what is its acceleration (using μ_k = μ_s)?
options: No, it slides with a ≈ 2.01 m/s² down
No, it slides with a ≈ 4.12 m/s² down
questions.explanation: Downhill: mg sin35° ≈ 11.24 N. Max static friction: μ_s mg cos35° ≈ 7.23 N. Since 11.24 > 7.23, it slides. a = g(sinθ - μ_k cosθ) = 9.8(0.5736 - 0.45×0.8192) ≈ 2.01 m/s².

questions.question: A 10 kg block slides up a 25° incline with initial speed 8.0 m/s. μ_k = 0.25. How far up the incline does it travel before stopping?
questions.explanation: Deceleration a = g(sinθ + μ_k cosθ) = 9.8(0.4226 + 0.25×0.9063) ≈ 6.36 m/s² down incline. Using v_f² = v₀² + 2ad: 0 = 8.0² + 2(-6.36)d → d ≈ 5.03 m.

questions.question: A force of 60 N parallel to the incline pushes an 8.0 kg block up a 30° incline. μ_k = 0.20. What is the block's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Downhill: mg sin30° = 39.2 N. Normal: mg cos30° ≈ 67.90 N. Friction: f_k = 0.20×67.90 ≈ 13.58 N (downhill). Net uphill: 60 - 39.2 - 13.58 = 7.22 N. a = 7.22/8.0 ≈ 0.90 m/s² up.

questions.question: A 4.0 kg block on a 20° incline is pushed with a 25 N horizontal force (not parallel to incline). μ_k = 0.15. Find the acceleration along the incline.
questions.explanation: Force components: parallel to incline = 25 cos20° ≈ 23.49 N up, perpendicular = 25 sin20° ≈ 8.55 N into incline. Normal N = mg cos20° + 8.55 ≈ 45.39 N. Friction f_k = 0.15×45.39 ≈ 6.81 N down incline. Downhill weight component: mg sin20° ≈ 13.41 N. Net uphill: 23.49 - 13.41 - 6.81 = 3.27 N. a = 3.27/4.0 ≈ 0.82 m/s² up.
